thread.title: Stanford's Morris powers U.S. team's victory
thread.title_full: Stanford's Morris powers U.S. team's victory

author: Associated Press
title: Stanford's Morris powers U.S. team's victory
text:
Stanford's Morris powers U.S. team's victory Associated Press Posted: 10/01/2015 08:54:16 PM PDT Updated: 10/02/2015 05:43:21 AM PDT Jordan Morris scored two goals, the second off a steal and feed from Wil Trapp, to give the United States a 3-1 victory over Canada on Thursday night in the opener of Olympic qualifying in Kansas City, Kansas. 
Morris, a 20-year-old Stanford junior, also scored in the first minute off a cross from Jerome Kiesewetter, and Luis Gil tacked on a penalty kick for the U.S. in extra time. 
Canada got its lone goal from Michael Petrasso after a corner kick in the 80th minute. 
It was a solid start for the Americans, who stumbled against the Canadians four years ago and ultimately failed to survive the group stage of qualifying for the London Games. 
The U.S. plays its second game in Group A on Saturday night against Cuba, which tied Panama 1-1 earlier in the day. 
Michel Platini will be without his closest adviser at UEFA as he seeks the FIFA presidency while embroiled in the Swiss investigation into corruption in the global governing body. Kevin Lamour, who heads Platini's office, has started a preplanned leave of absence with no date set for his return, UEFA said. 
Amy Rodriguez scored off a header in the 78th minute, and FC Kansas City sent midfielder Lauren Holiday into retirement with a 1-0 victory over the Seattle Reign in Portland, Oregon, for the National Women's Soccer League championship. Rodriguez scored off a cross from Heather O'Reilly. Advertisement College football The Mountain West could have as many as seven teams in postseason bowl games this year with official confirmation of the Arizona Bowl, which becomes the record 41st college football bowl game. 
Two teams from among the Mountain West, Conference USA and the Sun Belt Conference will be invited to the Arizona Bowl. The game was sanctioned by the NCAA in March, although the bowl's debut this year hinged on obtaining a title sponsor. Bowl officials secured Nova Home Loans to fill that role. 
The game will be played at Arizona Stadium in Tucson on Dec. 29. 
The Michigan at Maryland game Saturday was moved eight hours earlier because of Hurricane Joaquin. The Big Ten contest will start at 9 a.m. PDT. Golf Jimmy Mullen and Paul Dunne both marked their professional debuts with an 8-under 64 to grab a share of the lead after the first round of the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship in St. Andrews, Scotland. 
Mullen and Dunne went pro after helping Britain and Ireland beat the United States in the Walker Cup last month and had similar rounds, with each carding eight birdies and an eagle to go with two bogeys at Kingsbarns. They were tied with Kristoffer Broberg of Sweden, who had eight birdies in a flawless round at St. Andrews. The tournament is split among three courses, with players alternating between St. Andrews, Kingsbarns and Carnoustie. 
Rhein Gibson shot a 7-under 63 to take a one-stroke lead in the Web.com Tour Finals-ending Web.Com Tour Championship. The Australian had eight birdies and a bogey on Dye's Valley Course at TPC Sawgrass in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Tennis Serena Williams says she is withdrawing from the season-ending WTA Finals and the China Open to take time to heal after playing through injuries all year. Motor sports Jenson Button has decided against retirement and will remain with McLaren for the 2016 Formula One season. The 2009 world champion had been considering quitting after this season, but both sides announced that he would continue for another year. Wire services contributed to this report.
